translated: Record of Mount Lu, Scroll 5
List of Ancient Steles, Part 7
Preface: Mount Lu, from the Jin, Song, Qi, Liang, Chen, Sui, Tang, to the present dynasty, has been nearly 800 years.
In between, there have been descriptions of its decline and revival, prosperity and decline.
As the years go by, more and more are lost.
If Yin Zhongkan wrote a stele for Master Yuan,
in the Tianyou era it could still be seen in Guan Xiu's poem.
Now there is nothing left.
Now I record the steles, inscriptions, ranks, and dates of the five temples and observatories before the Five Dynasties, starting with the Eastern Forest of the Taiping era.
There are a total of 41.
The text is too long to include here.

Chapter 8: Ancient People's Inscriptions, Chapter 8: Ancient People's Inscriptions, I visited Donglin.
I quite like the inscriptions by people since the Tang dynasty in the houses.
The temple monks told me.
In past years, the houses were renovated.
Several hundred square boards.
The characters are dim.
Piled up in a secluded place.
No longer cherished.
Fortunately, these have not yet been thrown away.
Alas, many ancient people sighed that virtuous, accomplished, and outstanding people climbed mountains and looked into the distance.
All of them were buried and forgotten.
This is almost the case.
Now, from Yongtai onwards, seventeen people's inscriptions can be seen, starting with Yan Lugong.
I record this to make up for any losses.
In the Yongtai era of the Tang dynasty, on the bingwu day of the sixth month of summer in the third year.
Zhenqing was exiled to Jizhou as a punishment.
In the sixth month of summer, on the renwu day.
Xing Yinliang, Wei Baini, and Jia Yi visited Donglin Temple together.
The same is true for the two virtuous masters Xiyi and Huixiu, and the two Vinaya masters Quan and Yang Ni.
Looking up to the furnace peak of Mount Lu,
Thinking of the remaining virtues of Master Yuan.
Outside the Divine Movement Hall,
Bowing to the Saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robe,ğŸ”½Seeing the whisk fan of Master Shengfa,
Xie Lingyun's translation of the Nirvana Sutra and the palm-leaf Sanskrit scriptures,
I am not content with admiration.ğŸ”½I have casually carved it beside the stele of the two virtuous masters Zhang and Li and Chan Master YÃ©shÃ¨.
The record written by Yan Zhenqing of Lu Prefecture is carved on a stone beside the stele of Chan Master YÃ©shÃ¨ in Donglin Temple.
In the year of Yongtai, the third year of the Dali era of the Tang Dynasty, the year of Bingwu.
Zhenqing, due to his clumsiness, was demoted to an assistant in Jizhou.
In the sixth month of summer, on the Guihai day.
Xing Yinliang, Wei Baini, Jia Yi, Yang Ni,
Rested at Xilin Temple.ğŸ”½There was Vinaya Master Fazhen,ğŸ”½Who deeply studied the learning of pure precepts.
He was the direct disciple of Vinaya Patriarch Shien.
My cousin, the Acharya of Correct Meaning, was also there.
He remembered the legacy of the two masters, Yuan and Xian.
He led me to the upper floor.
He showed me the image of Vairocana Buddha painted by Zhang Sengyou, and the alms bowl embroidered with thread by Emperor Liang Wudi.
I then wrote a poem on the back of the stele inscription composed by Mr. Ouyang for the stele of Master Yong.
Mr. Yan Zhenqing of Lu wrote on the stone above the stele of Chan Master Yong of Xilin Temple.
Zi De of Longxi, Zi Xin of Qiaoguo, Xu Zhong of Henan, Xi Yuan of Jingzhao, and Mao Song of Longxi.
On the 11th day of the 4th month in the 10th year of the Dazhong era, we visited together. Mao Song wrote and carved the stone in Xilin Temple.
Wei Zhou, Junior Minister of Dali, concurrently Chief Minister of Censor-in-Chief, bestowed with purple gold fish bag.
In the 12th year of the Dazhong era.
In accordance with the edict, he was sent to the south of the Lingnan region to investigate.
On the 20th day of the 7th month, the 2nd day of the month.
Again, he passed by this canon.
In the past, it was established but was destroyed along with the temple.
Fortunately, it was hidden in the stone chamber by Chan Master Daoshen.
The monk Ming Shang was asked to fill the vacancy.
I was able to see the old continuation and was inspired to destroy the obstacles.
I donated three hundred thousand.
Again, I built a hall.
At that time, Hunan and Jiangxi were both in turmoil.
I took leave of the capital.
I went to dangerous states three times.
When I arrived here, I talked about the Way with Monk Ming for a few moments.
Then, I rode north.
My son Ze accompanied me and carved the stone at Donglin Temple.
This year, in the seventh month,
I was ordered to pacify the south of the Ling region.
In the beginning of the middle period, I went to the capital from Panyu.
In the meantime, the Hong army caused great disturbances.
So I went straight to Zhongling.
After arriving, I stayed.
In one night, I examined their sinister schemes.
I fully understood the situation.
The next day, I crossed the Zhang River.
On the twenty-ninth day, I rested here.
I talked about the mysteries with the two monks Ming and Shang.
At the same time, I visited the remaining sites of the Sutra Repository. In the evening, I left for the west. Sixty-four days.
I was in charge of investigating Jiangxi.
He then led the armies of Xiang, E, Xu, and Cai to the garrison.
On the twenty-seventh day of the eleventh month.
The troops arrived at Beitian.
Although I chose to serve in the military,
I was passing through Songmen.

Record of Mount Lu, Scroll 5, 1st proofread. The characters are not changed. The Record of Mount Lu in 5 scrolls in the Gaosiang Temple collection.
Scrolls 2 and 3 are from the Song Dynasty.
The remaining 3 scrolls are supplemented by old annotations.
However, all the taboo characters in the Song Dynasty are omitted.
It also comes from the Song Dynasty edition.
In the text, the taboo characters end with the taboo character Zhan of Emperor Gaozong.
However, the names and titles of Guangzong are not omitted.
It was published during the Gao and Guang eras.
This book is published by Shou-shan-ge-cong-shu in our country based on the Siku quanshu edition, but only the first three chapters are preserved as one volume.
The officials of the library think that the fourth and fifth chapters are lost.
Now the Song edition is actually chapter eight as volume five.
The first and second chapters are volume one.
The third chapter is volume two.
The fourth and fifth chapters are volume three.
The sixth chapter is volume four.
The seventh and eighth chapters are volume five.
The Shou-shan-ge edition not only lost the fourth chapter and below.
Its division of volumes is also not the old version at that time.
The officials of the library see the current version as one chapter.
They then suspect that only the fourth and fifth chapters are lost.
They are also mistaken.
The entire book is not known when it lost half of it.
The officials of the library think that the Yongle dadian edition also has only three chapters.
Then it has been like this since the early Ming.
The Eastern China edition is missing.
Outside the Song edition,
there is also a complete edition published in the tenth year of the Genroku era.
Now, taking the Genroku and ShÅzan editions,
and comparing them with the Song edition,ğŸ”½it is known that although the Genroku edition is complete, there are also errors and omissions.
The ShÅzan edition has even more errors and omissions.
In the first chapter, the ShÅzan edition omits Huiyuan's Record of Mount Lu.
It is only briefly mentioned here, with a few dozen characters. The Genroku edition does not omit it. In the second chapter, below the Shadowed Images,
the Genroku edition mistakenly includes more than ten lines, while the ShÅzan edition does not err. Farong's record says, Up to this point, it describes the wonders of Shimen. More than ten lines.
Moreover, Farong's record says, Up to this point, it refers to the arhat class. Three lines.
The ShÅzan edition omits both.
In the third chapter, the ShÅzan edition omits the words formerly the monk Miao of the Eastern Sea and so on, thirteen characters.
It also omits the words the source is due to fortune and so on, twenty-eight characters.
The sixth chapter of the Genroku edition lacks half a page of the poem on Rakushiji Temple.

The seventh chapter of the Genroku edition describes the errors in the steles of Donglin Temple.ğŸ”½It lists the stele inscriptions of the Buddhist canon of Donglin Temple and the stele inscription of the great virtuous Chan master.
Before the three steles of Huiyuan and others.
It is known that the Genroku edition is already not without errors.
This edition lacks the second page of volume one and the twenty-first and twenty-eighth pages of volume four.
Moreover, the preface by Li Chang is sewn into the third page of volume one.
Therefore, there should have been two missing pages above.
The second page of volume one is now supplemented based on the Genroku edition.
The other pages are also missing in the Genroku edition.
Regrettably, there are no other editions to refer to for supplementation.
